data.text: burunsuz-sele-onceden-vardi

Hello everyone, let's say it simply: my girlfriend has her intimate parts sour when we cycle for a few days. We're looking for solutions: has anyone tried saddles without a nose, like the one in the picture? Would you recommend it? Thanks in advance for your advice! üòä
I feel sorry for you if her girl parts are sour.
data.author: Dawn Alotta Seggs

data.text: interesting choice of words for sure.
data.author: Bud Thompson

data.text: üò≠üò≠üòõ
data.author: Wan Sabri

data.text: maybe a language thing,and don't forget Google translatie; it's a pain!
data.author: Greet Ellen

data.text: I think he probably meant "sore." üòÇ
data.author: Shaunanigan Wu

data.text: If you make plenty kilometres,wear a bikeshort with good saddlepadding in it, you should be okay .Do not wear underpants in your bikeshorts; they are not designed to do that it should'nt be SORE then!
data.author: Greet Ellen

data.text: I tend to agree about underpants. But on multi day trips I have found a pair of smart wool or merino wool underpants very comfortable under my bike shorts.
data.author: Ashlea Appelbaum

data.text: Could be; the more layers,the more friction I find...
data.author: Greet Ellen

data.text: I use a split saddle & it helps a lot. I think a certain amount of soreness is inevitable at least in the beginning or if you haven't ridden for a couple of months.
data.author: Ashlea Appelbaum

data.text: I think that is the thing; make your miles,and find out what works for you!
data.author: Greet Ellen

data.text: Thanks for your feedback. I am aware that a minimum amount of pain is inevitable on your bum (I experience the same), but would you say the same for your genitals? Cos to say it blently, that's where the problem is. Thanks for your responses, once again!
data.author: Blaise Peccia-Galletto

data.text: I agree, but on our last trip I ended up w a yeast infection & the layer of smart wool helped so much. I think my shorts got washed w too much detergent.
data.author: Ashlea Appelbaum

data.text: yes, conditioning/training leading up to a bike trip is essential. My first bike trip (365 miles over 6 days) was a last minute decision, I'd been rollerblading, not biking. I think I did 10 miles on my bike the week before we left. I was incredibly sore front to back (and every muscle in my body) for the entire ride. I make sure to train & build up tolerance before trips now.
data.author: Ashlea Appelbaum

data.text: as I said, make your miles, and find out what works for you!
data.author: Greet Ellen

data.text: I agree with a split saddle!!!Check out Terry cycling gear & seats made for women! Also seat adjustment helps!!! If she has to really reach to the handle bars it puts more pressure on the front of the pelvis. Try moving her seat forward just a little bit and/or tilte handlebars toward her or raising handlebars slightly!! Move seat or handle bars just a few millimeters at a time. It really makes a big difference!
data.author: Nicole Brown

data.text: Maybe tilt the saddle down just a hair, too?
data.author: Nora Somer

data.text: I personally have an ISM split nose saddle and have it slightly tilting down and no longer have any pain there at all, not even a little bit I can do multi day tours with zero issues.
data.author: Amber Hughes

data.text: Check out Terry. They make saddles especially for women. They have a tool on the website to identify the best chamois and the best saddle. Customer Service is excellent
data.author: Lukey Nuthmann

data.text:
Selle Anatomica. I suffered through several saddles before I found this one. Comfortable from day 1. Highly recommend it. Worth the price. And by the way, I don't wear padded bike shorts. Just a panty liner with my undies. https://selleanatomica.com/?_vsrefdom=adwords&gclid=CjwKCAjwuYWSBhByEiwAKd_n_hSApB_PjlAe3pMsThMctDevK-d0jmijxaYaLOnAdsWvBU7Ekl9pGhoCD6oQAvD_BwE
Leather Bike Saddles | Anatomical Saddles for Cyclists
selleanatomica.com
data.author: Gabi Gee

data.text: Agree My wife bought one the night before the El Tour Tucson Bike 110 miles the next day No pain
data.author: George Manning

data.text: Has your girlfriend considered a bike fit (there are plenty of videos on YouTube etc if it's not logistically/viable to get a professional one) it's not always the saddle itself but can be the positioning (too far back etc places additional unnecessary pressure on our most tender of tender parts üòØ I use a bioflex saddle with the cut out and it's fab, however it was a little uncomfortable when I first got it until I got the positioning just right üòÅ I also use a good fitting pair of bibs and bum butter as my Chamois cream which really helps. Finally and this is really personal so apologies (but might be useful I promise) Is your girlfriend an innie or an outie? *Question to be answered only between the two of you!!! üôà It does actually make a difference and a quick Google will help with a variety of (anatomy specific) suggestions. Good luck ü§û
data.author: Moya Terrett

data.text: Does her seat fit her sit-bones appropriately? A proper fitted seat plus padded shorts should be the magic formula to avoid soreness.
data.author: Chris Ripley-Olson

data.text: You first.. My LBS was happy a NYT article had an opinion endorsing noseless saddles, so we could sell the one we had .. & never restocked another..
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: I use Selle SMP and turn the nose down slightly...before that seat I was ready to quit biking!
data.author: Stacy Harris Hershkowitz

data.text: Find a saddle that fits. My girlfriend‚Äôs saddle has a very wide opening in the middle. She finds it very comfortable, I can‚Äôt ride it for more than a couple minutes.
data.author: Diego G√≥mez

data.text: Get her to Try some padded shorts first and experiment with a couple womens specific seats
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text:
bisaddle.com - get the short one
Adjustable Bike Seat | Cycling Saddle | Comfortable Bike Saddle
bisaddle.com
data.author: Nicholaus Rowe

data.text: Need good padded shorts, I have endura brand and chamois cream that should help too x
data.author: Julie Hallam

data.text: Maybe a new girlfriend whose sitbones fit the seat? Might be cheaper, just say'n.
data.author: Dan Hurley

data.text: If she hasn't already, I highly recommend that she gets her sit bones measured. A lot of bike stores will do this for free; you ask for a saddle measurement and they have you sit on a sort of gel thing for a few minutes so that you know your sit bone measurement. Getting a saddle that was the right size for my sit bones made a huge difference.
data.author: Carolyn Stallard

data.text: I used to have an SMP touring but never got used to it (real pain in the XXXX) so I switched to Brooks b17. It still hard as not broken in but way more comfortable already. Not really what you were asking but....
data.author: Remi Branly

data.text: Ism pr 3.0. I have these on both my bikes.
data.author: Kirsty Cambridge

data.text: A lot of your ability to control the bike comes from your thighs in contact with the nose of the saddle. She definitely doesn‚Äôt want to get rid of the saddle nose. Try, as others have recommended, a large cutout in the saddle and a bike fit. If she has to stretch for the bars, she‚Äôs going to feel it on her lady parts.
data.author: Sandra Kopriva

data.text: Set the saddle level. Try to find the best fit of saddle nose (saddle front side) from 0 degree (flat) to a little bit lower.
data.author: Eka Taruna

data.text: There are a lot of factors for saddle fit. Width has been mentioned, as has a cutout (of which there are different sizes) but shape matters too. Find a bike shop that will allow her to test saddles (on her bike or a jig set up to mimic it) so the best option(s) can be determined. A return/exchange policy is good too.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: If no saddle works‚Ä¶ Maybe a recumbent bike would solve the problem.
data.author: Jean Flamand

data.text: Seems like you bout to lose a girlfriend talkin bout her sour cream üòÇ
data.author: Brent Wander Borgemeister

data.text: SORE!
data.author: Joseph Attlee

data.text: I tried sitting on a saddle that didn't have a nose on it like that and I just felt like I was going to fall off of it
data.author: Danette Jeanne

data.text: Get a wider softer saddle. the nose is important, because as an extension of the seat tube, it anchors the seat tube between the legs, preventing it from moving from side to side. It's a critical component in leverage while pedalling. Otherwise, the arms will have to do all the work trying to keep the seat tube from moving side to side. maybe she could try a 2-wheeled recumbent. (not those trikes - they're too low (it can be hard for drivers to see you), are too wide and tippy when turning fast)
data.author: Timm Sima

data.text: Is she wearing padded bike shorts? Awkward question, but is she wearing underwear? This made a huge difference for me. It tends to shift around as we ride and cause discomfort. Also try chamois butt‚Äôr or some other cream to prevent uncomfortable rubbing. Seat position is also important. The front of the seat can punch you and make you very sore if it‚Äôs positioned too high
data.author: Meghan Bridget

data.text: My favorite saddle is the Gilles Berthoud Marie Blanque
data.author: Melia Sakimura

data.text: My wife has. She said it was like sitting on the edge of a shelf.
data.author: Matt Holtzlander
